loans.use: to buy items to sell like canned goods, softdriniks, and other groceries

loans.name: María Cecilia

texts.en:
Maria Cecilia is mother of two daughters, both of which are currently studying. She is married and lives in the city of Santa Catarina. It has been 5 years since she started her own business renting gowns for school events - she has always been interested in business. This generates an extra income for herself and it is enough to cover the expenses that her husband\\\'s salary cannot afford. For this reason she, day by day, struggles to keep and expand her business.

The love of her family and the support she gets from them has permitted Maria Cecilia to keep going with her project. She now needs a loan in the amount of $925 that she will repay in a term of 8-16 months. You can help her grow and this way, you can contribute towards a better quality of life for her daughters and permit the completion of their education. Do not doubt any longer, support her.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

María Cecilia es madre de dos hijas, ambas están estudiando, esta casada vive en la localidad de Santa Catarina. Ella desde hace 5 años que inició con su propio negocio de renta de vestuarios para eventos escolares, pues siempre ha tenido interés por lo negocios. Por su parte esto le generará ingresos extras que serán suficientes para cubrir ciertos gastos que con el sueldo de su esposo no pueden cubrir. Es por esto que ella si día a día lucha para mantener y hacer crecer su actividad.

El amor a su familia y el apoyo que recibe de ellos es lo que ha permitido que María Cecilia siga adelante con su proyecto. Ella ahora necesita e un crédito por la cantidad de $925 DLLS, mismos que cubrirá en un plazo de 8-16 meses. Tú puedes ayudarla a crecer y de esta manera contribuir a una mejor calidad de vida para sus hijas y la culminación de sus estudios. No lo dudes más y apóyala.

loans.use: purchase merchandise

loans.name: Numfor Tabitha

texts.en:
Tabitha is a single mother of three. She attended medical school and also training on pig farming. There is high demand for her services from her neighbors who cannot pay for public consultation fees. In addition, most of her neighbors collect the droppings of the pigs for manure on their farms. This increases food yields there and reduces hunger and malnutrition.

However she was prevented from operating a big medicine store because of finances. With loans from GHAPE, she opened a small store and bought piglets. Profit from the business helped her to fit doors and widows in her building. With high demand from the community, there is need for expansion.

Given $500, she is prepared to expand this business and buy more medicine together with four piglets and eight bags of feed. This will enable her to earn more profit to educate her children.

loans.use: Pharmacy and pig farming

loans.name: So Voeurn

texts.en: So Voeurn was married in 1990 and has 6 children, 2 daughters and 4 sons. Both her husband and herself grow vegetables, a business that they have continued from their parents. She  wants to borrow from MAXIMA for the first time with the loan amount of $150. The loan will be used for purchasing seeds, fertilizer and pesticides. She expects that after receiving the loan from MAXIMA, her farming can expand and the productivity will be better. This family will not have any problem to repay the loan.

loans.use: Purchasing seeds, fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Cecelien

texts.en: Cecelia E. is married, and has eight children. She is 52 years old, and lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. Cecelia has owned a restaurant for the past six years. She would like a loan to purchase more foods and drinks.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs and drinks

loans.name: Sabra

texts.en:
I am from Vehari, a small town located about 300km from Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. My husband and I are under a great deal of stress as we have nine children to feed, clothe and educate. My two elder sons work and my daughter stays at home as we cannot afford to send them all to school. 

I stay at home to take care of the children now. I used to sell some fruits and vegetables in my neighborhood, but that was unprofitable as neighbors liked to buy things on credit, which led to bad debt. My husband sells fruits and vegetables in the local market after purchasing them from nearby villages. Last year he was employed and made only $3 per day, but he has just set up his business. A $250 loan would help me and my husband to buy and sell more produce in the market and make $6 per day. With the additional profits, we will have more to eat and possibly be able to send our younger children to school.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Amara

texts.en:
Amara B. is 36 years old. He lives with his cohabitant and their 2 children in Yopougon, a crowded township in the northern area of the Abidjan district. Amara is an excellent dressmaker. He has a sewing shop in Yopougon. Amara is ambitious, a hard worker, and well-organized. With income from his business, Amara takes care of his family and pays the school expenses of his children, who both attend primary school near their home.

Amara will use the loan to purchase fabric to make dresses to sell for the upcoming celebrations: Aid El Kebir, Christmas, and New Year. This is a busy period for his business.

loans.use: Purchase fabric to make dresses to sell

loans.name: Yuldosh

texts.ru:
Yuldosh E., who is 59, is married ans has 6 children. He has been in the business of breeding and selling cattle for 10 years. Using the loan, Yuldosh plans to purchase 2 cows and forage. After feeding the cattle for 40 to 45 days, he plans to sell it and use the profits to repeat the original purchase. Extra money will be used for the needs of the family. Yuldosh plans to pay off the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova. Kiva Volunteer.

Эгамбердиев Юлдош, возраст – 59 лет, образование среднее, женат, имеет 6-х детей. Юлдош на полученный кредит планирует приобрести 2 головы крупного рогатого скота и корма для них. После их откормки через каждые 40-45 днец он планирует их продавать, а на вырученный деньги приобретать новый молодняк и корм, оставшуюся прибыль использовать на удовлетворение потребностей семьи. Этим видом деятельности он занимается уже в течение 10 лет. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase of 2 cows for future resale

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen E. is 38 years old and married with four children. She is an LAPO client and sells drinks and provisions for her business. She is from Edo State, Nigeria.

Helen needs a loan of $525 to buy more provisions and drinks for sale. She studied the business for 3 years and started hers in 2002.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and provisions for sale

loans.name: Maria Antonia

texts.es:
Mrs. Maria Antonia is a widow living in the humble area of Laureles Norte. Her two sons work as machine operators in a free trade zone and live at home with their mom. Thanks to her sons she is able to pay the utilties bills. Maria Antonia has a job as a domestic worker since they could not make ends meet with her son´s income alone.

Their humble home is in a very poor state as they are not able to pay for the necessary repairs. She is requesting a loan to refurbish her bedroom, which was recently damaged by heavy rains and wind.

Translated from Spanish by Henry Corral, Kiva volunteer.<

loans.use: Purchase cement blocks, cement, and a wooden door to refurbish a bedroom

loans.name: Aklamanou Yao And Sedeka Koffi Group

texts.en:
Aklamanou Y. and Sedeka K. are 2 young men, 33 years old and 30 years old, respectively. Mr. Y. is married and the father of 3 children, 2 of whom are in primary school and the third of whom is in high school. Mr. K. is married and the father of 1 child. These 2 men created their business, which is a general store, in 2003. They hope that with their loans they will be able to buy 20 sacks of rice, 15 1-pound sacks of sugar, 25 cartons of milk, and 20 cartons of canned goods. This will permit them to increase the capacity of their store, to respond to the needs of their clients, and to use their profits to better the lives of their respective families. These young entrepreneurs’ store is located in Avetonou, a small village located about 120 kilometers from Lomé, the Togolese capital. This location shows their necessity to be close to Lomé in order to buy goods to resell in Avetonou. Aklamanou Y. and Sedeka K. are good clients, as they have already benefited from 1 loan and made payments regularly.

Aklamanou Y. et Sedeka K. sont deux jeunes hommes âgés de 33 ans et 30 ans respectivement. Le premier est marié et père de 3 enfants dont 2 sont à l’école primaire et le troisième au collège tandis que le second est marié et père de 1 enfant. Ces deux personnes ont créé leur propre entreprise depuis 2003 et sont spécialisées en alimentation générale. Ils souhaitent avec les fonds qui seront mis à leur disposition acheter 20 sacs de riz, 15 sacs de sucres en poudre, 25 cartons de laits et 20 cartons de boîtes de conserves. Ce qui leur permettra d’augmenter la capacité de leur boutique pour répondre aux besoins de la clientèle et par là dégager plus de profits pour améliorer les conditions de leur famille respective. La boutique de nos jeunes entrepreneurs est située à Avetonou, un petit village situé à environ 120 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. D’où l’alimentation de leur boutique nécessite un déplacement sur Lomé. Aklamanou Y. et Sedeka K. sont de bon client puisqu’ils ont déjà bénéficié d’un crédit et les remboursements ont été réguliers.

loans.use: To buy 20 sacks of rice, 15 1-pound sacks of sugar, 25 cartons of milk, and 20 cartons of canned goods

loans.name: Chanthun

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthun H. and her husband got married in 2000. They have two children; one son and one daughter.  The family lives about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Chanthun has been working as a scarf-weaver for three years. She sells her finished products at a market in Phnom Penh. Her husband works in a garment factory.

Chanthun is requesting a loan of US$1,000 to purchase a semi-machine loom and cotton for weaving.

loans.use: Purchase of a semi-machine loom and cotton for scarf-weaving

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more fish for sale

loans.name: Murodjon

texts.ru:
Murodjon R. lives in the city of Nurek. He is 22, single and does not have children. He has been trading for the past 3 years. He has a small place where he sells DVDs. Murodjon would like to increase his sales by receiving a loan. This will help him increase his family income and help his parents. He plans to repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva Volunteer.

Рискулов Муроджон житель города Норак. Возраст 22 года, холост , детей не имеет.Уже три года занимается торговлей . Имеет торговую точку , где продает ДВД диски. Хочет увеличить товарооборот путем получения кредита. Это поможет ему увеличить доходы семьи и помочь родителям. Погасить кредит планирует 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase new items for sale

loans.name: Thou

texts.en:
Thou N. is a dried fish seller in the market and she makes about $5 per day. Her husband is an ox merchant. He makes about $1.60 per day. They have five children; one of whom is married, living in Kork Daung Village, Siem Reap Province, Cambodia.

One of their daughters is a tailor who graduated recently from professional school. She operates a tailoring business, but she doesn’t have enough capital to run the business. So Mrs. N. is requesting a loan of $1000 to build a store for her daughter’s tailor business. N.'s husband is pictured.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To build a store for her daughter’s tailor business

loans.name: Evaline

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 40-year-old Evaline K. from Dar es Salaam. She is a wonderful woman who has devoted her career to the care and education of the Tanzanian young. Evaline runs a nursery school in Dar, which she established in 2002. With two other employees, Evaline nurtures young Tanzanian boys and girls every day of the week during the school year and prepares them to enter elementary school. We could really use more dedicated people like her!

Evaline’s school earns her approximately US$ 200 in monthly profits. She is requesting US$ 525 from Kiva for capital to renovate her school, specifically the classrooms, and employ more teachers to deal with the nursery school's growing needs.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence the poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To renovate her nursery school and to employ additional teachers

loans.name: Gledis

texts.es:
La señora Gledis, socia del BC “Mujeres Rumbo al Desarrollo”, vive en la Región y provincia de San Martín, distrito de Morales. Se dedica a la venta de  golosinas, chupetes, dulces regionales y frutas como el aguaje y maní. Realiza las ventas de manera ambulatoria en una de las principales calles de su distrito, frente a la plaza de armas, lugar muy concurrido por lo que le va muy bien hasta la fecha.   

Con este préstamo de S/. 800, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará aguaje en saco, azúcar en saco, bolsitas para chupetes, dulces de diferente sabores y variedades, maní en kilos para tostar y darle diversos usos (dulce de maní o saladito). 

Gledis tiene 35 años de edad, vive con su esposo y 2 de sus hijos quienes aún dependen de ella. Gladis es una mujer muy perseverante y responsable, con ganas de salir adelante y apoyar a su esposo en la economía de la casa. Desea tener una casa y poner un negocio en la misma.
texts.en:
Mrs Gledis is a partner of the "Women Towards Development" communal bank. She lives in the region and province of San Martin in the district of Morales. Mrs Gledis sells candies, lollipops, peanuts, regional sweets and fruits like aguaje. She is a street vendor and is settled in one of the main streets of her district, in front of the main square, as it is a very crowded spot, her business has done very well so far. Gledis requests a loan of S/. 800, which she will pay in 4 installments. With it, she will buy sugar, candies of different types and flavors, peanuts (which she will toast and sell either sweet or salty), aguaje and little bags for the candies. Gledis is 35 years old, she lives with her husband and together they have 2 kids who still depend on them. Gledis is a very persevering and responsible woman and she has the drive to succeed and to help her husband with the house expenses. Gledis hopes to own a house and to open up a little business herself.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Almendares Leistner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sugar, candies of different types and flavors, peanuts, aguaje and little bags for the candies

loans.name: Sakina's Group

texts.en:
Sakina baji is a wife of L. M. and lives in a small town named Bund Road in the city Lahore, Pakistan. She has been living in this town for the last 15 years. She is the mother of seven children: six sons and one daughter. Her elder son is a driver by profession and drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). The others are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Sakina baji's husband is a contractor and provides construction supplies to builders. Sakina baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She is applying for a loan to buy more construction supplies like sand and cement to expand her husband's business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Nabeela baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Kosar baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk selling business. Asma baji wants a loan to buy welding tools.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies
